for 35 years pastor Patrick mccahill has
led a deaf mass here at st. Elizabeth's
church in Manhattan but shrinking
attendance here and across the city is
leading to a restructuring the
Archdiocese of New York recently
announced that it is merging and closing
dozens of churches including st.
Elizabeth's parishioners here have been
told that starting in August of 2015
their parish will be merging with st.
monica's a larger Church a 10-minute
walk away that's a lovely place it
really is very bright and big butt butt
big distant our Father who art in heaven
hallowed be thy name I'm kingdom come
I'd be all the way up here they'd be all
the way down there it feels very distant
to my sensibilities everything is visual
you have to be able to see things well
and clearly most people sit in the back
of the church deaf people all want to
sit in the front of the church so they
can see what's going on I see this is a
absolutely opposite to what the stated
goal of strengthening parish life is I
see it as kind of destroying the Deaf
powers that we have here besides mass
st. Elizabeth's is a center for deaf
activities and parishioners often stay
for hours to socialize the new church
lacks an accessible space that could be
used for things like this Thanksgiving
dinner
I'm shocked that they would move us out
of here for deaf people it's like home
I've been coming here since I was a
little girl I got communion hear
confirmation here what about us deaf
people seems like we can just be pushed
aside many of us are from different
communities Staten Island Brooklyn
Westchester we come here this is the
only place we can get together it's
better than going to a bar I prefer
being together here it's more like a
family this is the one deaf church here
in New York it can't close I cherish
this church it's my church I refuse to
let it close the archdiocese says that
it is open to exploring other locations
for the deaf community but that's
staying at st. Elizabeth's is not an
option
